```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(leaflet)
library(dplyr)
library(geojsonio)
library(ggplot2)
library(arulesViz)
```

```{r get_shape_data, include=FALSE, cache=TRUE}
utlas <- geojson_read("https://opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/d3d7b7538c934cf29db791a705631e24_0.geojson", what = 'sp')
# drop Wales
utlas <- utlas[grep('E', utlas$ctyua17cd), ]
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}

map <- leaflet(utlas) %>%
  # Base groups
  addTiles(group = "OSM (default)") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Stamen.Toner, group = "Toner") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Stamen.TonerLite, group = "Toner Lite") %>%
  # Overlay groups
  # addCircles(~long, ~lat, ~10^mag/5, stroke = F, group = "Quakes") %>%
  addPolygons(
    fill = T, weight = 2, color = "#FFFFFF", group = "Outline") %>%
  # Layers control
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c("OSM (default)", "Toner", "Toner Lite"),
    overlayGroups = c("Outline"),
    options = layersControlOptions(collapsed = FALSE)
  )
map
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
